channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Structural mechanism of angiogenin activation by the ribosome

A secondary atmosphere on the rocky Exoplanet 55 Cancri e

Accurate structure prediction of biomolecular interactions with AlphaFold 3

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07489-8

Publisher Correction: High carrier mobility along the [111] orientation in Cu2O photoelectrodes

item.title: Alphafold 3.0: the AI protein predictor gets an upgrade
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01385-x

Deepmind’s protein-structure predictor adds other molecules to the mix, and a big step towards a ‘nuclear clock’.
item.dc:title: Alphafold 3.0: the AI protein predictor gets an upgrade
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Mapping genotypes to chromatin accessibility profiles in single cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07388-y

The JAK2V617F mutation leads to epigenetic rewiring in a cell-intrinsic and cell-type-specific manner, influencing inflammation states and differentiation trajectories in patients with myeloproliferative neoplasms.
item.dc:title: Mapping genotypes to chromatin accessibility profiles in single cells
item.dc:creator: Franco Izzo
Robert M. Myers

item.title: Observation of Nagaoka polarons in a Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07272-9

Emergence of Nagaoka polarons and kinetic magnetism is observed in a Hubbard system realized with strongly interacting fermions trapped in a triangular optical lattice.
item.dc:title: Observation of Nagaoka polarons in a Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator
item.dc:creator: Martin Lebrat
Muqing Xu
Lev Haldar Kendrick
Anant Kale
Youqi Gang
Pranav Seetharaman
Ivan Morera
Ehsan Khatami

Markus Greiner

item.title: Full-colour 3D holographic augmented-reality displays with metasurface waveguides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07386-0

We develop a method for providing high-quality, holographic, three-dimensional augmented-reality images in a small form factor suitable for incorporation in eyeglass-scale wearables, using high-refraction-index glass waveguides with nanoscale metasurfaces, and incorporating artificial intelligence.
item.dc:title: Full-colour 3D holographic augmented-reality displays with metasurface waveguides
item.dc:creator: Manu Gopakumar
Gun-Yeal Lee
Suyeon Choi
Brian Chao
Yifan Peng
Jonghyun Kim
Gordon Wetzstein

item.title: The refinery of the future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07322-2

Efforts to find renewable alternatives to fossil fuels that might enable a carbon-neutral society by 2050 are described, as well as outlining a possible roadmap towards a refinery of the future and evaluating its requirements.
item.dc:title: The refinery of the future
item.dc:creator: Eelco T. C. Vogt
Bert M. Weckhuysen

item.title: All-optical subcycle microscopy on atomic length scales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07355-7

All-optical subcycle microscopy is achieved on atomic length scales, with picometric spatial and femtosecond temporal resolution.
item.dc:title: All-optical subcycle microscopy on atomic length scales
item.dc:creator: T. Siday
J. Hayes
F. Schiegl
F. Sandner

R. Huber

item.title: The intrinsic substrate specificity of the human tyrosine kinome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07407-y

An atlas of the substrate specificities for the human tyrosine kinome reveals diversity of motif specificities and enables identification of kinase–substrate relationships and kinase regulation in phosphoproteomics experiments.
item.dc:title: The intrinsic substrate specificity of the human tyrosine kinome

item.title: Chemical short-range disorder in lithium oxide cathodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07362-8

The introduction of chemical short-range disorder substantially affects the crystal structure of layered lithium oxide cathodes, leading to improved charge transfer and structural stability.
item.dc:title: Chemical short-range disorder in lithium oxide cathodes
item.dc:creator: Qidi Wang
Zhenpeng Yao

item.title: Boron catalysis in a designer enzyme
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07391-3

A completely genetically encoded boronic-acid-containing designer enzyme was created and characterized using X-ray crystallography, high-resolution mass spectrometry and 11B NMR spectroscopy, allowing chemistry that is unknown in nature and currently not possible with small-molecule catalysts.
item.dc:title: Boron catalysis in a designer enzyme
item.dc:creator: Lars Longwitz
Reuben B. Leveson-Gower
Henriëtte J. Rozeboom
Andy-Mark W. H. Thunnissen
Gerard Roelfes

item.title: Genome organization around nuclear speckles drives mRNA splicing efficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07429-6

Nuclear speckles are shown to have a functional role in mRNA splicing, whereby dynamic three-dimensional organization of DNA around these structures mediates splicing efficiency.
item.dc:title: Genome organization around nuclear speckles drives mRNA splicing efficiency
item.dc:creator: Prashant Bhat
Amy Chow
Benjamin Emert
Olivia Ettlin

item.title: Ligand cross-feeding resolves bacterial vitamin B<sub>12</sub> auxotrophies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07396-y

Two species of auxotrophic marine bacteria are shown to share precursors to synthesize the essential cofactor vitamin B12, and such ligand cross-feeding may be a common phenomenon in the ocean and other ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Ligand cross-feeding resolves bacterial vitamin B<sub>12</sub> auxotrophies
item.dc:creator: Gerrit Wienhausen
Cristina Moraru
Stefan Bruns
Den Quoc Tran
Sabiha Sultana
Heinz Wilkes
Leon Dlugosch
Farooq Azam
Meinhard Simon

item.title: Structural pharmacology and therapeutic potential of 5-methoxytryptamines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07403-2

Detailed analyses of the serotonin receptor 5-HT1A and the psychedelic 5-methoxy-N,N-dimethyltryptamine reveal the differences in receptor structural pharmacology that mediate signalling specificity, efficacy and potency, findings that may facilitate the development of new neuropsychiatric therapeutics.
item.dc:title: Structural pharmacology and therapeutic potential of 5-methoxytryptamines
item.dc:creator: Audrey L. Warren
David Lankri
Michael J. Cunningham
Inis C. Serrano

Vaclav Havel
Scott J. Russo
Dalibor Sames
Daniel Wacker

item.title: An atomic boson sampler
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07304-4

Boson sampling using ultracold atoms in a two-dimensional, tunnel-coupled optical lattice is enabled by high-fidelity programmable control with optical tweezers of a large number of atoms trapped in an optical lattice.
item.dc:title: An atomic boson sampler
item.dc:creator: Aaron W. Young
Shawn Geller
William J. Eckner
Nathan Schine
Scott Glancy
Emanuel Knill
Adam M. Kaufman

item.title: Directly imaging spin polarons in a kinetically frustrated Hubbard system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07356-6

A triangular-lattice Hubbard system realized with ultracold atoms is used to directly image spin polarons, revealing ferromagnetic correlations around a charge dopant, a manifestation of the Nagaoka effect.
item.dc:title: Directly imaging spin polarons in a kinetically frustrated Hubbard system
item.dc:creator: Max L. Prichard
Benjamin M. Spar
Ivan Morera
Eugene Demler
Zoe Z. Yan
Waseem S. Bakr

item.title: Self-oscillating polymeric refrigerator with high energy efficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07375-3

We report on a near-zero-power flexible heat pump that uses both electrocaloric and electrostrictive properties of a tailored polymer to create a chip-scale refrigerator device.
item.dc:title: Self-oscillating polymeric refrigerator with high energy efficiency
item.dc:creator: Donglin Han
Yingjing Zhang
Cenling Huang
Shanyu Zheng

item.title: Targetable leukaemia dependency on noncanonical PI3Kγ signalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07410-3

Using a multimodal approach across acute leukaemias, a targetable PI3Kγ dependency in leukaemias is explored.
item.dc:title: Targetable leukaemia dependency on noncanonical PI3Kγ signalling
item.dc:creator: Qingyu Luo
Evangeline G. Raulston

item.title: Long-range order enabled stability in quantum dot light-emitting diodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07363-7

Improving the long-range order of the quantum dots in perovskite LEDs can markedly enhance their operational stability.
item.dc:title: Long-range order enabled stability in quantum dot light-emitting diodes
item.dc:creator: Ya-Kun Wang
Haoyue Wan
Sam Teale
Luke Grater
Feng Zhao
Zhongda Zhang
Hong-Wei Duan
Muhammad Imran

Liang-Sheng Liao

item.title: Subaerial weathering drove stabilization of continents
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07307-1

The geological histories of Archaean regions indicate that stabilization of the Earth’s continents and the formation of cratons was driven by continental emergence and subaerial weathering.
item.dc:title: Subaerial weathering drove stabilization of continents
item.dc:creator: Jesse R. Reimink
Andrew J. Smye

item.title: Discovery of potent small-molecule inhibitors of lipoprotein(a) formation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07387-z

Biochemical screening and optimization identify small molecules that inhibit the formation of lipoprotein(a), and these inhibitors reduce the levels of Lp(a) in several animal models, suggesting that they could provide a therapeutic option in humans.
item.dc:title: Discovery of potent small-molecule inhibitors of lipoprotein(a) formation
item.dc:creator: Nuria Diaz

item.title: Label-free detection and profiling of individual solution-phase molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07370-8

Enhanced light–molecule interactions in high-finesse fibre-based Fabry–Pérot microcavities are used to detect and profile individual unlabelled solution-phase biomolecules, leading to potential applications in the life and chemical sciences.
item.dc:title: Label-free detection and profiling of individual solution-phase molecules
item.dc:creator: Lisa-Maria Needham

item.title: Computationally restoring the potency of a clinical antibody against Omicron
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07385-1

By demonstrating a computational approach to restore the clinical efficacy of a COVID-19 antibody, the potential to rapidly update clinical antibodies is explored.
item.dc:title: Computationally restoring the potency of a clinical antibody against Omicron

item.title: Decoupling excitons from high-frequency vibrations in organic molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07246-x

A molecular design strategy for reducing the vibration-induced non-radiative losses in emissive organic semiconductors is realized by decoupling excitons from high-frequency vibrations.
item.dc:title: Decoupling excitons from high-frequency vibrations in organic molecules
item.dc:creator: Pratyush Ghosh
Antonios M. Alvertis
Rituparno Chowdhury

item.title: Measurement of the superfluid fraction of a supersolid by Josephson effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07361-9

A new method based on the Josephson effect is described, allowing to measure the superfluid fraction of a supersolid, which captures the effect of spatially periodic modulation leading to reduction in the stiffness of superfluids.
item.dc:title: Measurement of the superfluid fraction of a supersolid by Josephson effect
item.dc:creator: G. Biagioni
N. Antolini

L. Pezzè

M. Fattori

M. Inguscio
L. Tanzi
G. Modugno

item.title: Lithium tantalate photonic integrated circuits for volume manufacturing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07369-1

Electro-optical photonic integrated circuits based on lithium tantalate perform as well as current state-of-the-art ones using lithium niobate but the material has the advantage of existing commercial uses in consumer electronics, easing the problem of scalability.
item.dc:title: Lithium tantalate photonic integrated circuits for volume manufacturing
item.dc:creator: Chengli Wang
Zihan Li

Tobias J. Kippenberg

item.title: Retuning of hippocampal representations during sleep
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07397-x

Using a Bayesian learning approach, a study tracks the spatial representations by individual hippocampal cells over time in freely moving rats, and provides insights into how ensemble patterns form and reconfigure during sleep.
item.dc:title: Retuning of hippocampal representations during sleep
item.dc:creator: Kourosh Maboudi
Bapun Giri
Hiroyuki Miyawaki
Caleb Kemere
Kamran Diba

item.title: A meta-analysis on global change drivers and the risk of infectious disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07380-6

Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, managing ecosystem health, and preventing biological invasions and biodiversity loss could help to reduce the burden of plant, animal and human diseases, especially when coupled with improvements to social and economic determinants of health.
item.dc:title: A meta-analysis on global change drivers and the risk of infectious disease
item.dc:creator: Michael B. Mahon

item.title: Fusion of deterministically generated photonic graph states
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07357-5

Using an optical resonator containing two individually addressable atoms in a single cavity, fusion of deterministically generated photonic graph states to create ring and tree graph states with up to eight qubits is demonstrated.
item.dc:title: Fusion of deterministically generated photonic graph states
item.dc:creator: Philip Thomas
Leonardo Ruscio
Olivier Morin
Gerhard Rempe

item.title: Complete biosynthesis of QS-21 in engineered yeast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07345-9

QS-21—an FDA-approved vaccine adjuvant—and several structural analogues of QS-21 can be synthesized in engineered yeast strains, and this process is much less laborious compared with the conventional mode of extraction from the Chilean soapbark tree.
item.dc:title: Complete biosynthesis of QS-21 in engineered yeast

item.title: ‘Ghost roads’ could be the biggest direct threat to tropical forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01295-y

By using volunteers to map roads in forests across Borneo, Sumatra and New Guinea, an innovative study shows that existing maps of the Asia-Pacific region are rife with errors. It also reveals that unmapped roads are extremely common — up to seven times more abundant than mapped ones. Such ‘ghost roads’ are promoting illegal logging, mining, wildlife poaching and deforestation in some of the world’s biologically richest ecosystems.
item.dc:title: ‘Ghost roads’ could be the biggest direct threat to tropical forests

item.title: Vibration isolation could boost performance of near-infrared organic LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01170-w

The development of high-performance organic LEDs and other devices that emit near-infrared light has been hindered by seemingly fundamental features of the light-emitting molecules. A potential solution has been identified.
item.dc:title: Vibration isolation could boost performance of near-infrared organic LEDs
item.dc:creator: Margherita Maiuri

item.title: Vaccine-enhancing plant extract could be mass produced in yeast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01210-5

The Chilean soapbark tree is the source of QS-21 — a valuable but hard-to-obtain vaccine additive. Yeast strains engineered to express all components of the QS-21 biosynthetic pathway provide an alternative route to this therapeutic.
item.dc:title: Vaccine-enhancing plant extract could be mass produced in yeast
item.dc:creator: Ryan Nett

item.title: Bird flu in US cows: where will it end?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01333-9

Scientists worry that the H5N1 strain of avian influenza will become endemic in cattle, which would aid its spread in people.
item.dc:title: Bird flu in US cows: where will it end?
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Toad psychedelic points to biological target for antidepressants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01296-x

A hallucinogenic compound secreted by toads has served as a springboard for research into the therapeutic benefits of psychedelics. The findings suggest that these compounds exert antidepressant effects in part by binding an under-appreciated target in the brain.
item.dc:title: Toad psychedelic points to biological target for antidepressants

item.title: Dozens of Brazilian universities hit by strikes over academic wages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01355-3

Some professors and staff members have been on strike for as long as four weeks as they seek better conditions at their institutions.
item.dc:title: Dozens of Brazilian universities hit by strikes over academic wages
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Major AlphaFold upgrade offers boost for drug discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01383-z

Latest version of the AI models how proteins interact with other molecules — but DeepMind restricts access to the tool.
item.dc:title: Major AlphaFold upgrade offers boost for drug discovery
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: How I fled bombed Aleppo to continue my career in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01374-0

Aref Kyyaly’s quest to find a safe place, away from Syria, to do research taught him perseverance. Don’t give up, is his advice.
item.dc:title: How I fled bombed Aleppo to continue my career in science
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: Tashni’s first tunnel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01282-3

Digging deep.
item.dc:title: Tashni’s first tunnel
item.dc:creator: Robert Blasiak

item.title: Quantum tunnelling of electrons brings ultrafast optical microscopy to the atomic scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01294-z

The oscillating electromagnetic fields that carry light can cause electrons to tunnel back and forth through a potential energy barrier. Remarkably, this alternating current can coherently emit measurable light waves — an unexpected process that can be exploited to build an optical microscope that undercuts existing spatial and temporal limitations.
item.dc:title: Quantum tunnelling of electrons brings ultrafast optical microscopy to the atomic scale

item.title: Physicists move closer to an ultra-precise ‘nuclear’ clock
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01353-5

Timekeepers based on energy shifts in atomic nuclei could transform fundamental-physics research.
item.dc:title: Physicists move closer to an ultra-precise ‘nuclear’ clock
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Did atmospheric weathering help Earth’s earliest continents to survive?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01306-y

What stabilized and strengthened the oldest, most robust blocks of continental crust billions of years ago during the Archaean eon has long been a mystery. It seems that a surprise helping hand might have come from the air above.
item.dc:title: Did atmospheric weathering help Earth’s earliest continents to survive?
item.dc:creator: Claire E. Bucholz

item.title: Powerful ‘nanopore’ DNA sequencing method tackles proteins too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01280-5

Latest methods bring the speed, portability, and long read lengths of nanopore sequencing to proteomics.
item.dc:title: Powerful ‘nanopore’ DNA sequencing method tackles proteins too
item.dc:creator: Caroline Seydel

item.title: This Earth-like exoplanet is the first confirmed to have an atmosphere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01332-w

55 Cancri e is too hot to support life as we know it, but could provide clues about Earth’s formation.
item.dc:title: This Earth-like exoplanet is the first confirmed to have an atmosphere
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Illuminating ‘the ugly side of science’: fresh incentives for reporting negative results
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01389-7

New data repositories and alternative journals and workshops offer routes for sharing negative results — which could help to solve the reproducibility crisis and give machine learning a boost.
item.dc:title: Illuminating ‘the ugly side of science’: fresh incentives for reporting negative results
item.dc:creator: Rachel Brazil

item.title: Reinvent oil refineries for a net-zero future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01323-x

From petrol to plastics, oil-derived products define modern life. A bold plan to change that comes with huge costs — but researchers and policymakers should take it seriously.
item.dc:title: Reinvent oil refineries for a net-zero future

item.title: Finding millennia-old ‘monumental’ corals could unlock secrets of climate resilience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01342-8

Finding millennia-old ‘monumental’ corals could unlock secrets of climate resilience
item.dc:title: Finding millennia-old ‘monumental’ corals could unlock secrets of climate resilience
item.dc:creator: Simone Montano
Federica Siena
Giovanni Strona

item.title: Japan can embrace open science — but flexible approaches are key
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01340-w

Japan can embrace open science — but flexible approaches are key
item.dc:title: Japan can embrace open science — but flexible approaches are key
item.dc:creator: Kazuki Ide

item.title: The dream of electronic newspapers becomes a reality — in 1974
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01220-3

Efforts to develop an electronic newspaper providing information at the touch of a button took a step forward 50 years ago, and airborne bacteria in the London Underground come under scrutiny, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: The dream of electronic newspapers becomes a reality — in 1974

item.title: Beware of graphene’s huge and hidden environmental costs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01339-3

Beware of graphene’s huge and hidden environmental costs
item.dc:title: Beware of graphene’s huge and hidden environmental costs
item.dc:creator: Shijie Guo
Zihan Cai
Yanchao Yang
Qingyuan Ding

item.title: Old electric-vehicle batteries can find new purpose — on the grid
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01287-y

An algorithm can monitor the health of retired vehicle batteries used to store surplus power fed into the electrical grid.
item.dc:title: Old electric-vehicle batteries can find new purpose — on the grid

item.title: Countering extreme wildfires with prescribed burning can be counterproductive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01341-9

Countering extreme wildfires with prescribed burning can be counterproductive
item.dc:title: Countering extreme wildfires with prescribed burning can be counterproductive
item.dc:creator: David Lindenmayer
Philip Zylstra

item.title: Hacking the immune system could slow ageing — here’s how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01274-3

Our immune system falters over time, which could explain the negative effects of ageing.
item.dc:title: Hacking the immune system could slow ageing — here’s how
item.dc:creator: Alison Abbott

item.title: Expat grants won’t fix Brazilian research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01324-w

Permanent jobs and fairer hiring practices would encourage overseas scientists to return.
item.dc:title: Expat grants won’t fix Brazilian research
item.dc:creator: Juliano Morimoto

item.title: US funders to tighten oversight of controversial ‘gain-of-function’ research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01377-x

New policy on high-risk biology studies aims to address criticism that previous rules were too vague.
item.dc:title: US funders to tighten oversight of controversial ‘gain-of-function’ research
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: How artificial intelligence is helping Ghana plan for a renewable energy future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01316-w

The technology is helping the West African nation to invest wisely in infrastructure, prioritising energy and food security, but also human health.
item.dc:title: How artificial intelligence is helping Ghana plan for a renewable energy future
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: ‘Risk-of-death’ AI save lives in hospital trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01382-0

An algorithm trained on electrocardiograms reduced deaths among high-risk patients by 31%. Plus, an AI transcription tool seems to hallucinate harmful text and a robot that efficiently combines bouncing and flying.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: ‘Risk-of-death’ AI save lives in hospital trial
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Argentina’s pioneering nuclear research threatened by huge budget cuts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01283-2

President Javier Milei is making moves to partially privatize the sector, but in the meantime, projects have paused.
item.dc:title: Argentina’s pioneering nuclear research threatened by huge budget cuts
item.dc:creator: Martín De Ambrosio
Fermín Koop

item.title: Editorial Expression of Concern: Leptin stimulates fatty-acid oxidation by activating AMP-activated protein kinase
item.content:encoded:

item.title: I make 3D models of conifer needles to explore their climate effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01281-4

Jan Pisek seeks a better understanding of how forests absorb sunlight, carbon and heat.
item.dc:title: I make 3D models of conifer needles to explore their climate effects
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: Quantum control of a cat qubit with bit-flip times exceeding ten seconds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07294-3

A type of qubit that has inherent resistance to bit-flip errors has been manipulated with a bit-flip time of more than 10 s without losing that error protection.
item.dc:title: Quantum control of a cat qubit with bit-flip times exceeding ten seconds

item.title: Venus water loss is dominated by HCO<sup>+</sup> dissociative recombination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07261-y

Water loss to space late in Venus history is shown to be more active than previously thought, with unmeasured HCO+ dissociative recombination dominating present-day H loss.
item.dc:title: Venus water loss is dominated by HCO<sup>+</sup> dissociative recombination
item.dc:creator: M. S. Chaffin
E. M. Cangi

item.title: Microbubble ultrasound maps hidden signs of heart disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01194-2

Cardiovascular disease claims more lives each year than do the two next-deadliest diseases combined. An ultrasound technique that tracks tiny gas-filled bubbles could pave the way towards improved early detection.
item.dc:title: Microbubble ultrasound maps hidden signs of heart disease
item.dc:creator: Elisa E. Konofagou

item.title: China's Chang'e-6 launches successfully — what happens next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01345-5

Scientists have high hopes for the first mission to collect rocks from the far side of the Moon.
item.dc:title: China's Chang'e-6 launches successfully — what happens next?
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: How rich is too rich?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01276-1

Where should society draw the line on extreme wealth? A fresh account sets out the logic and suggests how to redress inequality.
item.dc:title: How rich is too rich?
item.dc:creator: Lucas Chancel

item.title: Puppy-dog eyes in wild canines sparks rethink on dog evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01315-x

The eyebrows of the African wild dog have scientists wondering whether other dogs can make the irresistible ‘puppy-dog eyes’ expression.
item.dc:title: Puppy-dog eyes in wild canines sparks rethink on dog evolution
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: From multiverses to cities: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01277-0

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: From multiverses to cities: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Streamlined skull helps foxes take a nosedive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01267-2

Some fox species leap up and pounce head first into snow to capture prey that they hear below the surface. An analysis of the forces involved reveals how the shape of the skull has evolved to minimize damage from this behaviour.
item.dc:title: Streamlined skull helps foxes take a nosedive
item.dc:creator: Mary Abraham

item.title: Mount Etna’s spectacular smoke rings and more — April’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01250-x

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: Mount Etna’s spectacular smoke rings and more — April’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Hunger on campus: why US PhD students are fighting over food
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01279-y

Graduate students are relying on donated and discounted food in the struggle to make ends meet.
item.dc:title: Hunger on campus: why US PhD students are fighting over food
item.dc:creator: Laurie Udesky

item.title: France’s research mega-campus faces leadership crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01319-7

The contest to elect the next president of Paris-Saclay University has collapsed, reflecting wider issues at the giant research centre.
item.dc:title: France’s research mega-campus faces leadership crisis
item.dc:creator: Barbara Casassus
